title: How to Avoid Blunders in Chess

steps.headline: Look over the board carefully.
steps.description: Before and after each move, do a complete scan of the pieces in play and make observations about what’s changed. A crowded chessboard can be a lot to take in, but it’s critical to be aware of all the possible lines of attack and defense within a given configuration. With enough practice, you’ll begin to recognize the significance of what you’re seeing without having to think about it consciously. Keeping tabs on the board actually becomes more important as the pieces start to thin out and you and your opponent have more room to plot out and execute each move.

steps.headline: Pay attention to the position of your opponent’s pieces.
steps.description: Don’t just focus on how your end of the game is arranged—theorize about how your opponent might use their own pieces to block, confuse, or attack. Close inspection may help you spot a weakness in their defense or pick up on a deceptive play before it has a chance to put you at a disadvantage. Take note when your opponent moves the same pieces several times in a row, or appears to be ignoring key pieces. They may be setting something up.

steps.headline: Keep an eye out for surprise attacks.
steps.description: Always examine the configuration of active pieces from multiple angles. Experienced players will sometimes attempt to lure you in by staging a clever diversion, then catch you off guard with an unexpected move. Be careful not to let yourself get cornered or pinned in on more than one side. Never go out of your way to capture an opponent's pawn. An experienced player may intentionally leave them unprotected in order to bait you into sacrificing one of your more valuable pieces.

steps.headline: Understand how each piece moves.
steps.description: If you’re new to chess, take some time to learn about the various pieces and their unique patterns of movement. Knowing their strengths and weaknesses will enable you to use them more effectively while avoiding careless errors and oversights. Each player has a total of 8 small pawns. Pawns can only move forward a single space at a time, never backwards or sideways. They capture enemy pieces diagonally. The 2 crowned rooks on either end of the board can move and capture forward or sideways any number of spaces, making them quite useful. There are 2 horse-shaped knights, which move and capture in an L-shaped pattern, either forward 2 spaces and over 1, or forward 1 space and over 2. The 2 bishops stationed between the rooks and knights can move and capture any number of spaces diagonally. When used together with the rooks, they can be very effective both offensively and defensively. The queen is the most powerful piece on the board, as it can move an unlimited number of spaces forward and backward, sideways, or diagonally. Because your queen is so versatile, you should avoid losing it at all costs. The king is the most important piece in chess, and the one the game is centered around protecting. It can move a single space in any direction. Consider each piece’s unique pattern of movement when trying to determine the best way to cover ground, shift into a defensive position, or launch an attack.

steps.headline: Visualize each move before you make it.
steps.description: Imagine what might happen once you’ve changed a piece’s position on the board. What’s the most logical outcome? Are there any subtle details you’re missing? If you’re uncertain how your opponent is likely to answer, it might be a good idea to consider an alternate strategy. Never assume that you know how an opponent will react to a move. Taking their reactions for granted could leave you blind to counters or holes in your own gameplan.

steps.headline: Familiarize yourself with basic chess tactics.
steps.description: When you’re not playing, brush up on successful tactical motifs pioneered by other influential players throughout history. These are usually prescribed series of moves designed to bait an opponent into committing a blunder. Some of the most basic chess tactics include forks, pins, and skewers. In a fork, you take advantage of a piece's unique pattern of movement to attack more than 1 of your opponent's pieces at a time. Pinning involves attacking a piece that, if moved, will allow you to take a more valuable piece behind it. A skewer is the opposite of a pin. During a skewer, you'll target a high-ranking piece, forcing your opponent to move it so you can capture a less valuable piece. By adding a few cunning tactics to your arsenal, you stand to become a stronger player both offensively and defensively. He has been a part of the United States' Webster SPICE national chess champion team and is also a two-time Israeli national chess champion. Vitaly Neimer			International Chess Master				Tactics are some of the most important aspects of chess. Tactics are combinations of movements. One of the simplest ones is a fork, where you move one piece and attack two or more pieces. Use tactics and try solving as many puzzles as you can to get a sense of the board and any danger.

steps.headline: Make sure your most important pieces are protected at all times.
steps.description: Never get so focused on setting up your next line of attack that you leave your power pieces defenseless. Endangering your king will cost you the game, of course, but losing your queen, rook, bishop, or knight can also leave you at a serious disadvantage and make it harder to mount a comeback. Knights are especially useful for defending your royal pieces. Their long reach and ability to move at unusual angles makes them highly valuable. Keep a rook next to your king at all times in case you need to "castle." If your king is in immediate danger, you can cross over with your rook to check your opponent's attacking piece and place your king a safe distance away.

steps.headline: Take your time.
steps.description: Get in the habit of scanning the board for at least 30 seconds before making a move, even if you appear to have no other option. The longer you spend sizing up each situation, the more opportunity you’ll have to formulate long-term strategies. Slowing down the pace of the game will also help you detect threats that you might not have noticed otherwise. Keep your mind on the board, not the clock. Obsessing over how much time you’re taking could cause you to act too quickly and put yourself at risk. During heated competition, it’s not uncommon for players to take several minutes between moves.

steps.headline: Stay focused.
steps.description: Devote the same amount of caution and forethought to each and every move throughout the entire game. All too often, players get in a hurry to get through a sequence they've spent a long time setting up and end up seeing their plans backfire as a result. One of the worst blunders you can make is playing absentmindedly. It isn’t just cornered players who are prone to losing focus. Oftentimes, the player with the advantage will become overconfident in their position and begin to play haphazardly.

steps.headline: Try to get into your opponent’s head.
steps.description: Ask yourself what reason they could have for taking the approach they did. A master of chess puts just as much thought into the other player's game as their own. Otherwise, you’ll only be seeing half of the action unfolding before you. It’s important to be able to put yourself in your opponent’s shoes. Working out how you might outsmart yourself if you were in their position can offer clues as to the tactics they’re likely to employ.

steps.headline: Think 1-2 moves ahead.
steps.description: Rather than just scouting your next move, apply your insights into your opponent’s psychology to predict what they might do, then follow up accordingly. Looking ahead makes it possible to pull off intricate tactics and enjoy much more control than you would have by playing reactively. Don’t be too set on the idea of how a sequence will play out. If your opponent doesn’t react the way you anticipated, you need to be willing to adjust your strategy on the fly. The most effective tactics are the ones that leave your opponent with no choice but to move the way you planned. Being able to accurately predict 2-3 moves in advance won't always be possible, as chess is a richly complex game in which everything can change in an instant.
